_data.title: About KNO
_data.description: All information about the KNO.cards platform
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is KNO.cards
cards.a: A platform that holds a library of decks on different topics

cards.q: What does the deck hold
Are the decks on a particular subject or few subjects only
cards.a: No. They are and can be on different subjects that are of likely interest to the visitors of this library.

cards.q: Is it like Wikipedia
Does that mean the KNO decks will not have depth
What topics are covered in the General Series
cards.a: These give information on a topic of universal appeal within a subject

cards.q: What topics are covered in the Professional Series
cards.a: These have topics more suited for someone connected to the respective field

cards.q: In what way is KNO different from other information websites
cards.a:
1. One, it is **topical** providing a way for a learner to update herself / himself
2. It follows the flashcards format for a more **natural and engaging** experience
3. It is **easily viewable** and **conveniently sharable** between friends

cards.q: How often will topics get added to KNO
cards.a: On a daily basis

cards.q: Who creates the content of the decks
cards.a: The KNO team. Folks who have an interest in an area and keep abreast of the latest happenings on different subjects.

cards.q: How do you ensure that the information is correct and upto date
So what are the terms for accessing the decks
cards.a: The information is provided on a **as-is basis**.

cards.q: Is there any registration or login required to access the decks
cards.a: No

cards.q: What information of the user is being captured while they access a deck
cards.a: The platform uses Google Analytics to get statistics of usage. This is meant to provide the team with information on which decks are more popularly accessed and help improve the usefulness of KNO.

cards.q: What should I do if the information mentioned in the deck has errors
Is there a way to suggest a topic that is not available in the KNO library
cards.a: Yes, in the Home page, there is a *suggestion* icon which lets you share a topic of interest. Once we receive your suggestion, we will assign it to an internal expert who will put together relevant content and post a deck.

cards.q: For other matters, is there a way to reach the KNO team
cards.a: Email us on: **connect2rmr@gmail.com**

cards.q: What is a Carbon Footprint
cards.a: Carbon footprint is the total greenhouse gas emissions caused by an individual, event, organization, service, place or product

cards.q: What are Greenhouse Gas Emissions
cards.a: These are emissions from human activity that strengthen the Greenhouse Effects (*separate deck available*)

cards.q: What are Greenhouse Effect
cards.a: The greenhouse effect is a process when energy from sun goes through its atmosphere and warms Earth's surface, however the atmosphere prevents the heat from returning directly to space, resulting in a warmer planet

cards.q: How are these emissions expressed
cards.a: As carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e)

cards.q: What would be somes example of estimated CO2e
cards.a:
1. A load of laundry washed at room temperature will be **0.6 kg** of CO2e
2. A new car has a foot print of approximately **9 tonnes** of CO2e
3. A flight has an emission equivalent of more than **200 gms** of CO2e per km and a rail coach amost a quarter of it

cards.q: What determines the CO2e of a product
cards.a:
The true carbon footprint of any product includes emissions resulting from: 
- the manufacturing process
- the transportation of the product to warehouses etc
- indirect emissions, such as those caused by the manufacturing of the materials used

cards.q: As individuals why should we care about our carbon footprint
cards.a: Because of our lifestyles and choices made, we add to the greenhouse gas emissions that causes global warming

cards.q: What are some of the choices individuals can make to reduce our carbon footprint
cards.a:
Yes. Small changes can be made. Some of these are:
1. Consume local (*less transportation*) and seasonal products (*less storage*)
2. Avoid excessive plastic packaging
3. Use public transport (*distributed footprint*) instead of private vehicles
4. Unplug electronic equipment when charged

cards.q: What is a **Carbon Calculator**
cards.a: These are websites that provide a convenient form-based enquiry of one's lifestyles to give an estimate of the total footprint for a period

cards.q: What is **Carbon accounting**
cards.a: It refers to processes used to measure how much carbon dioxide equivalents an organization or individual emits

cards.q: What is **Carbon credits**
cards.a: A carbon credit is a tradable certificate or permit representing the right to emit one tonne of carbon dioxide or the equivalent amount of a different greenhouse gas

cards.q: What is **Carbon Offset**
cards.a: A carbon offset is a reduction or removal of emissions of carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases made in order to compensate for emissions made elsewhere

cards.q: Besides Carbon footprints are there other ecological footprints
cards.a:
Yes.
1. **Water footprints**: that determine the extent of water use in relation to consumption by people
2. **Land footprints**: that determine the real amount of land required to produce a product

_data.title: 4th Industrial Revolution
_data.description: Get to know about the 4th Industrial Revolution
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the 4th Industrial Revolution mean
cards.a: Simply put, **4IR** is a combination of humans and machines in the workplace

cards.q: What were the earlier three Industrial Revolutions
cards.a:
1. **First Revolution** was Mechanisation
2. **Second Revolution** was Electrification
3. **Third Revolution** was Automation and Globalisation

cards.q: Who first spoke of the Fourth Industrial Revolution
cards.a: **Professor Klaus Schwab**, founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum described it in his book, *The Fourth Industrial Revolution* in 2016

cards.q: How did the term: **Industrial Revolutions** come about
cards.a: The noted 19th century economic historian **Arnold Toynbee** mentioned it while describing British economic development between 1760 to 1840

cards.q: In what way is 4IR different from 3IR
cards.a: There has been rapid changes to process and societal patterns caused by interconnectivity and smart automation

cards.q: What and when was the 1st Industrial Revolution
cards.a: It was a transition from **hand production** methods to **machine production** using steam power. The period was between **1760 to 1840**

cards.q: What and when was the 2nd Industrial Revolution
cards.a: It was called the *Technological* revolution and marked by **railroad and telegraph networks**. The period was between 1871 and 1914

cards.q: What and when was the 3rd Industrial Revolution
cards.a: It was called the *Digital* revolution and marked by **computer and communication technology**. The period was after World War II

cards.q: What are the characteristics of 4IR
cards.a:
It is characterized by a fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines between the physical, digital, and biological spheres
1. **Interconnection** between machines and sensors (IoTs)
2. **Information Transparency** letting organisations take decisions based on data
3. **Technical Assistance** offered by computing systems to aid human decisions
4. **Decentralised Decisions** taken by automated systems based on data available

cards.q: What are some of the components of 4IR
cards.a:
- mobile devices
- IoTs
- smart sensors
- big data analytics
- on-demand computer resources

cards.q: What is distinctive about 4IR in comparison to earier revolutions
cards.a: The speed of breakthroughs being witnessed is unpreceded in history

cards.q: What are some of these breakthroughs
cards.a:
- Artificial Intelligence / Robotics
- The Internet of Things / Autonomous Vehicles
- Nanotechnology / Biotechnology
- Materials Science / Energy Storage
- 3D Printing / Quantum Computing

cards.q: What are some of the challenges 4IR brought along
cards.a:
1. Privacy concerns
2. *Big Brother is watching* concerns 
3. People have to adapt to new skill sets (*else become unemployable*)
4. Lack of regulation leading to unclear legal issues

_data.title: COP 26
_data.description: A overview of the climate change conference 26
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is the full form of COP 26
cards.a: Conference of Parties 26

cards.q: What is this conference about
cards.a: It was the United Nations sponsored conference on **Climate Change**

cards.q: What is 26
cards.a: The 26th edition of the UN Climate Change Conference

cards.q: Where and when was it held
Who was the President of the Conference
cards.a: Mr Alok Sharma, a UK cabinet minister

cards.q: What are these conferences
cards.a: The United Nations Climate Change Conferences are yearly conferences held in the framework of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)

cards.q: What is the purpose of the Climate Change Conferences
cards.a:
1. Essentially, to access the progress in dealing with climate change
2. To get countries bide by the obligations discussed in earlier COP conferences

cards.q: How many countries participated in COP 26
cards.a: 197 participating agencies

cards.q: Were there specific goals to the COP 26
cards.a:
1. Secure global net zero by mid-century and keep 1.5 degrees within reach
2. Adapt to protect communities and natural habitats
3. Mobilise finance
4. Work together to deliver

cards.q: What were the achivements listed during COP 26
cards.a:
1. Over 90% of world GDP is now covered by net zero commitments and 153 countries have put forward new 2030 emissions targets.
2. 80 countries are now covered by either Adaptation Communications or National Adaptation Plans to increase preparedness to climate risks.
3. Developed countries have made progress towards delivering the $100 billion climate finance goal and will reach it by 2023.
4. Collaboration between governments, businesses and civil society will work to deliver climate goals faster

cards.q: What is **Net Zero** related to environment
cards.a: A term, popularized - *thanks to COP26* - for saying a country, company, or product does not contribute to global greenhouse gas emissions

cards.q: What were the key takeaways from COP 26
cards.a:
1. Strengthen efforts to build resilience to climate change
2. Curb greenhouse gas emissions
3. Provide the necessary finance for both
4. transparent reporting of climate actions and support provided or received, including for loss and damage

cards.q: Why is Paris Agreement considered important
cards.a:
Back in 2015, at COP21, in Paris, something momentous happened:
- every country agreed to work together to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees and aim for 1.5 degrees
- to adapt to the impacts of a changing climate
- to make money available to deliver on these aims

cards.q: Where and when was the first COP conference held
cards.a: In Berlin, Germany between 28-Mar-1995 to 7-Apr-1995

cards.q: When and where is the next COP 27 conference scheduled
cards.a: In Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt scheduled in 2022

_data.title: World's first Pig Heart Human Transplant
_data.description: Info on the first pig to human heart transplant
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: Who was the recepient of first pig-heart transplant
cards.a: David Benett at the age of 57

cards.q: When and where was the transplant done
cards.a: On 7-Jan-2022, in Baltimore, Maryland, US

cards.q: Who performed the operation
cards.a: A team of surgeons from the University of Maryland School of Medicine led by Dr Bartley Griffith and Dr. Mohiuddin

cards.q: Why was the pig chosen as the animal whose heart could be transplanted
cards.a: Because they are very similar in structure, size and function to human hearts

cards.q: Was there any treatment done to the pig before using the heart
cards.a: The pig heart had **10 genetic modifications**, including the removal of four pig genes and the addition of six human genes to ensure the host body did not reject the pig heart

cards.q: How long did the procedure take
cards.a: 7 hours

cards.q: Were any previous experiments done before the doctors undertook this procedure
cards.a:
1. In 2021, surgeons at New York University Langone Health transplanted kidneys from the same line of genetically modified pigs into two legally dead people with no discernible brain function. 
2. The organs were not rejected, and functioned normally while the deceased recipients were sustained on ventilators.
 
> As it is often said, science always **stands on the shoulders of giants**

cards.q: Was there no alternative treatment for the patient
cards.a: The patient, who had arrhythmia, was not a viable candidate for the heart transplant list or an artificial heart pump

cards.q: What is Arrhythmia
cards.a: An arrhythmia occurs when a person’s heart beats irregularly

cards.q: What is **Xenotransplantation**
cards.a: It is the process of transplanting live organs, tissues, or cells from a nonhuman animal into a human

cards.q: When was the first human heart transplant done
cards.a: Dr Christiaan Barnard with his team, performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant operation on 3-Dec-1967

_data.title: Covid and its Variants
_data.description: General info about covid and its variants
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Covid
cards.a: Short for **Covid-19**, it is the newly identified disease that causes respiratory illness

cards.q: When was Covid identified
cards.a: World Health Organisation (WHO) first learned of this new virus on 31 December 2019

cards.q: How did Covid get its name
cards.a: **Co** is for Corona, **Vi** for Virus and **D** for Disease

cards.q: What is the difference between Covid-19 and SARS-Cov-2
cards.a: Covid-19 is the infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus

cards.q: Who issued the official names of Covid-19 and SARS-Cov-2
cards.a: The official names COVID-19 and SARS-Cov-2 were issued by WHO on 11 February 2020

cards.q: What is the full form of SARS-Cov-2
cards.a: **S**evere **A**cute **R**espiratory **S**yndrome - **Co**rona**V**irus - **2**

cards.q: What is the incubation period of Covid
cards.a: 1 to 14 days

cards.q: What are the common symptoms of Covid
cards.a:
1. Fever or chills
2. Cough
3. Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
4. Fatigue
5. Muscle or body aches

cards.q: How does any virus spread
cards.a: To spread, a virus needs to infect a host, replicate and produce lots of copies of itself

cards.q: What is a virus Mutation
cards.a: When a virus replicates it doesn't always manage to produce an exact copy of itself via a process called Mutation

cards.q: In what way does a virus change
cards.a: The new copied virus may start to differ slightly in terms of its genetic sequence

cards.q: What is a Variant
cards.a: Viruses that get produced with new mutations are called variants

cards.q: What is a Strain
cards.a: When a new variant has different functional properties to the original virus and becomes established in a population, it is sometimes referred to as a new **strain** of the virus

cards.q: So is a strain and variant the same
cards.a: All strains are variants, but not all variants are strains

cards.q: How are the variants of Covid-19 named
cards.a: An expert group convened by WHO recommended using letters of the Greek Alphabet, i.e., Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta

cards.q: What is the first Covid variant named
cards.a: Alpha

cards.q: What is the list of variant names so far
cards.a:
1. Alpha 
2. Beta  
3. Gamma
4. Delta
5. Omicron

cards.q: What are some of the variants being monitored
cards.a:
1. Lambda
2. Mu

cards.q: What is the full form of PCR test
cards.a: **P**olymerase **C**hain **R**eaction **T**est

cards.q: What is the full form of RT-PCR test
cards.a: **R**everse **T**ranscription **P**olymerase **C**hain **R**eaction  Test

cards.q: What does PCR testing do
cards.a: PCR tests are used to directly screen for the presence of viral RNA (Ribonucleic Acid) in the body

cards.q: What is the full form of CT value in a RT-PCR Test
cards.a: **C**ycle **T**hreshold value

cards.q: What is the CT value that determines whether a patient has covid or not
cards.a: Popularly a value below 35 is considered positive and above being negative (*this threshold can vary from country to country*)

cards.q: What are covid antibody / antigen tests
cards.a: They are tests done to detect corona proteins in a person's body to know if they has immunity against covid-19

cards.q: Can an antigen test detect presence of covid
cards.a: No, they cannot diagnose covid

_data.title: Greenhouse Gases
_data.description: An understanding of Green House Gases
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is **Greenhouse effect** and **Greenhouse gases**
cards.a: The **Greenhouse effect** is the process by which energy from the sun warms our planet but the atmosphere prevents the heat from returning back due to **Greenhouse gases** resulting in a warmer planet

cards.q: Is it not good to retain the heat from the Sun
cards.a: Yes, if not Earth will always be below freezing temperature. This natural Greenhouse effect is why we survive

cards.q: Then, why is it considered harmful
cards.a: Because the amount of heat retained is more than required gradually making the planet warmer which will eventually destroy it

cards.q: Which are the Greehouse gases
cards.a:
The primary greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere are:
- Water Vapor
- Carbon Dioxide
- Methane
- Nitrous Oxide 
- Ozone 
- Chloroflurocarbons

cards.q: Which are the major Greenhouse gases that prevent heat from radiating back
cards.a:
1. Carbon Dioxide
2. Nitrous Oxide
3. Methane
4. Chloroflurocarbons

cards.q: Why is there always mention about Carbon Dioxide
cards.a: Because that constitutes a major percentage (about 76%) of the GHG

cards.q: What happens when the heat is not radiated back
cards.a: Certain quantity of the heat is required to maintain equitable temperature on earth, but over time because of the increase in these gases the planet has become warmer

cards.q: What happens if the planet becomes warmer
cards.a: It contributes to extreme weather, wildfires, droughts and food supply disruptions that may eventually lead to extinction of animal species

cards.q: Which industries are the major emitters of GHG
cards.a:
1. Power generation via coal
2. Transportation
3. Agriculture
4. Deforestation

cards.q: Why happens when we use coal
cards.a: Coal when it is burnt to generate energy releases tremendous amount of Carbon Dioxide. This causes a disproportionate amount of CO2 in the atmosphere causing global warming. This happens with other fossil fuels like petroleum products too.

cards.q: How does Agriculture contribute to GHG
cards.a:
1. Cattle herds produce Methane when they gas. Methane is 30 times more potent than CO2.
2. Crop fertilisers contain Nitrous Oxide which is 300 times more potent than CO2.

cards.q: How does Deforestation increase GHG
cards.a: Trees, we know, absorb Carbon Dioxide, during the photosynthesis process. This reduces the amount of CO2. However, with large deforestation, the world is denied of this beneficial process.

cards.q: How can humans reduce GHG
cards.a:
1. Switch to cleaner energy providers
2. Drive less and walk / cycle more
3. Wash clothes without using warm water in washing machine to save energy
4. Eat seasonal or locally produced fruits/vegs since they have lower transportation costs
5. Replace light bulbs with energy-efficient ones

_data.title: Internet of Things
_data.description: All you need to know about Internet of Things (IoT)
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is Internet of Things
cards.a: The Internet of Things (IoT) describes the network of physical objects  - **things**  - that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the internet

cards.q: How is it different from computers, mobiles and TVs which also are part of the internet
cards.a: In that all of the above require humans to use them for purposes of connecting and exchanging data unlike IoTs

cards.q: What are examples of some IoTs
cards.a:
IoTs are smart devices like:
1. **Activity trackers** like exercise bands
2. **Home Security devices** like door-bell cameras, smart lights
3. **AR Glasses** that provide information when focussed on an object
4. **Motion Detectors** in buildings, bridges and dams
5. **Smart Cars**

cards.q: What are **Smart Devices**
cards.a: A smart device is an electronic device, generally connected to other devices or networks via different wireless protocols such as Bluetooth, NFC, Wi-Fi etc., that can operate to some extent interactively and autonomously

cards.q: What is the purpose of IoTs
cards.a: The purpose is to have devices that self report in real-time, improving efficiency and bringing important information to the surface more quickly than a system depending on human intervention

cards.q: Which was the first smart device and when was it invented
cards.a: In 1982 a modified Coca-Cola vending machine at Carnegie Melon Institute was connected to Arpanet (*the internet of those times*)

cards.q: Who coined the phrase Internet of Things
cards.a: **Kevin Ashton**, a British Technologist, coined the phrase 'Internet of Things' in 1999

cards.q: Where do IoTs get their power
cards.a:
- **battery** based 
- ride on **host system power**
- connected to **power supply**

cards.q: What is Capsule Endoscopy
What are the disadvantages of IoT
cards.a:
- security and privacy
- too much dependency on technology
- unemployment

cards.q: Who is James Webb on whose name this telescope has been named after
cards.a: He was the administrator of NASA from 1961 to 1968 during the Mercury, Gemini, and much of the Apollo programs

cards.q: What are some key dates related to the telescope launch and deployment
cards.a:
1. **Launched** on 25-Dec-2021
2. **Deployed** on its *halo orbit* on 24-Jan-2022
3. **Detected** first photon on 3-Feb-2022

cards.q: What are the goals of JWST
cards.a:
1. to search for light from the first stars and galaxies that formed in the universe after the Big Bang
2. to study galaxy formation and evolution
3. to understand star formation and planet formation
4. to study planetary systems and the origins of life

cards.q: Which agencies have built this telescope
cards.a:
1. NASA (National Aeronautics Space Administration) of USA 
2. ESA (European Space Agency)
3. CSA (Canadian Space Agency)

cards.q: How far above Earth is the telescope placed
cards.a: Approximates 1500,000 kms / 930,000 mi from earth

cards.q: How big and heavy is JWST
cards.a:
- **Weight**: approx 6000 kgs / 14000 lbs
- **Sunshield size**: approx 20 m x 15 m / 66 ft x 46 ft

cards.q: What is Sunshield
cards.a:
1. A protective shield of the telescope and its instrumentation from the light and heat of the Sun, Earth, and Moon
2. To enable the infrared telescope to function at or below its design temperature of 40 kelvins (−233 °C; −388 °F).

cards.q: What is the **collecting area** of JWST
What is the importance of the **Halo Orbit** that the telescope operates in
cards.a: It lets the telescope stay in line with the Earth as it moves around the Sun. This allows the satellite's large sunshield to protect the telescope from the light and heat of the Sun and Earth

cards.q: Prior to JWST which was the largest space telescope
cards.a: Hubble Space Telescope (HST)

cards.q: Is it under operation
cards.a: Yes, it was launched in the 1990s and is expected to last till 2040s

cards.q: How different is JWST over HST
cards.a:
- Hubble's dimensions are 13 m x 4 m / 43 ft x 14 ft in comparison to 20 m x 15 m / 66 ft x 46 ft of JWST
- Hubble's weight is 11,000 kgs in comparison with 6000 kgs of JWST
- Hubble's collecting area is 4.5 sq metres in comparison to 25 sq metres in JWST

cards.q: What is the expected cost of JWST
cards.a: Lifetime cost is expected to be $ 9.7 billion

cards.q: What is the expected life of JWST
cards.a: 20 years

cards.q: What is a Malaria Vaccine
When was the first Malaria vaccine approved by WHO
cards.a: World Health Organisation approved the use of the first Malaria vaccine in Oct 2021

cards.q: What is the vaccine called
cards.a: RTS,S popularly known by its brandname **Mosquirix**

cards.q: Why did it take so many years to create a vaccine
cards.a: Because of the technical complexity of developing any vaccine against a parasite

cards.q: What is the complexity with a parasite
cards.a: Malaria parasites have a complex life cycle, and there is poor understanding of the complex immune response to malaria infection

cards.q: What is a Parasite
cards.a: Parasite is an organism that feeds with parts or vital products from another living organism called host

cards.q: How is a Parasite different from a Bacteria
cards.a: Parasite needs a host to survive, while a Bacteria can survive without a host

cards.q: How is a Parasite different from a Virus
cards.a:
1. While both require a host, Parasites can produce independently while viruses can reproduce using the host.
2. Parasites are much bigger than viruses

cards.q: What is the efficacy of the RTS,S vaccine
cards.a: 77% as per the clinical trials

cards.q: Why is the development of a Malaria Vaccine an achievement
cards.a: Every year there are more than 200 million reported cases of malaria leading to over 600,000 deaths. Now, having a vaccine will help prevent cases as well as reduce deaths.

cards.q: Who developed the Malaria Vaccine
cards.a: The Pharma company, GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) collaborated with Malaria Vaccine Initiative (MVI) to develop the vaccine supported by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation

cards.q: How many years did it take to develop the vaccine
cards.a: Over 20 years

cards.q: How does a Mosquitto cause Malaria
cards.a:
1. When a malaria-infected mosquito plunges her needle-like mouth through human skin, she releases **immature forms** of the parasites into the person's bloodstream. 
2. From there, they travel to the liver, then to red blood cells. 
3. The infected cells burst, releasing millions of daughter parasites which infect other red blood cells. 
4. The cycle persists until the parasites are killed

cards.q: How is Malaria treated
cards.a: Using Antimalarial medication that kill the malaria parasites during their development stage in the liver and red blood cells

cards.q: How long does it take for the Malarial drugs to work
cards.a: Approximately 2 weeks

cards.q: What are Internet Slangs
cards.a:
Acronyms that folks use in social posts to save space and time of typing. Some examples are:
- **MSG**: Message
- **FYI** : For Your Information
- **ASAP** : As Soon As Possible
- **IMO**: In My Opinon / **IMHO**: In My Humble Opinion
- **LOL**: Laughing Out Loud
- **KISS**: Keep It Simple Stupid

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that expresses some *emotion*
1. **JK**
2. **WUWH**
3. **ADIH**
4. **IFYP** 
5. **TIME**
cards.a:
1. **JK**: Just Kidding
2. **WUWH** : Wish You Were Here
3. **ADIH** : Another Day In Hell
4. **IFYP** : I Feel Your Pain
5. **TIME** : Tears In My Eyes

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that is a good way to *end a conversation*
1. **BFN**
2. **G2G**
3. **TTYL**
4. **PTB**
5. **TMB**
cards.a:
1. **BFN** : Bye For Now
2. **G2G** : Got to Go
3. **TTYL** : Talk To You Later
4. **PTB** : Please Text Back
5. **TMB** : Tweet Me Back

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs to *warn about parents!*
1. **PAW**
2. **PITR**
3. **PBB**
4. **POMS**
5. **KPC**
cards.a:
1. **PAW** : Parents Are Watching
2. **PITR** : Parent In The Room
3. **PBB** : Parent Behind Back
4. **POMS** : Parent Over My Shoulder
5. **KPC** : Keeping Parents Clueless

cards.q: What is the difference between **Abbreviation** and **Acronym**
cards.a: An **Abbreviation** is typically a shortened form of words used to represent the whole (*such as Dr. or Prof.*) while an **Acronym** contains a set of initial letters from a phrase that usually form another word (*such as radar or scuba*).

cards.q: What is an **Initialism**
cards.a: Initialisms are when you abbreviate a word to its initials and you say the individual letters

cards.q: What are some examples of Initialism
cards.a:
- ENT which is Ear-Nose-Throat (*we spell out the letters*)
- IBM which is for International Business Machines
 
While
- AIDS (*Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome*) is an acronym since we do not spell out the letters.

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs to *express opinion*
1. **OMDB**
2. **POV**
3. **SRLY**
4. **YGTR**
5. **NTH**
cards.a:
1. **OMDB** : Over My Dead Body
2. **POV** : Point Of View
3. **SRLY** : Seriously
4. **YGTR**: You Got That Right
5. **NTH** :Nice To Have

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that are of the *as far as I ...* series
1. **AFAIK**
2. **AFAIR**
3. **AFAIC**
4. **AFAICT**
5. **AFAIU**
cards.a:
1. **AFAIK** : As Far As I Know
2. **AFAIR** : As Far As I Remember
3. **AFAIC** : As Far As I'm Concerned / Care
4. **AFAICT** : As Far As I Can Tell
5. **AFAIU** : As Far As I Understand

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that are used to express *love*
1. **IMU**
2. **FIMH**
3. **AML**
4. **DFWLU**
5. **BTWIAILWU**
cards.a:
1. **IMU** : I Miss You
2. **FIMH** : Forever In My Heart
3. **AML** : All My Love
4. **DFWLU**: Don't Forget Who Loves You
5. **BTWIAILWU**: By The Way I Am In Love With You

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that are used to express *laughter*
1. **FOFL**
2. **CSL** 
3. **BWL** 
4. **BMGWL** 
5. **LHO**
cards.a:
1. **FOFL** : Falling On Floor Laughing
2. **CSL** : Can't Stop Laughing
3. **BWL** : Bursting With Laughter
4. **BMGWL** : Bursting My Guts With Laughter
5. **LHO** : Laughing Head Off

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that are used about *friends*
1. **BFF**
2. **BFFN**
3. **FWB** 
4. **WAGS** 
5. **LJBF**
cards.a:
1. **BFF** : Best Friends Forever
2. **BFFN** : Best Friends For Now
3. **FWB** : Friends With Benefits
4. **WAGS** : Wives And Girlfriends of Sports Stars
5. **LJBF** : Lets Just Be Friends

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that are used to express *fear*
1. **FOMO**
2. **FOGC**
3. **FUD** 
4. **FOLO**
cards.a:
1. **FOMO** : Fear Of Missing Out
2. **FOGC** : Fear of Getting Caught
3. **FUD** : Fear, Uncertainty, and Disinformation
4. **FOLO** : Fear of Losing Out / Family Of Loved Ones!

cards.q:
Can you guess some of these slangs that are of the *keep ...* series
1. **KUGW**
2. **KUFC**
3. **KUPO** 
4. **KUNC**
5. **KUBC**
cards.a:
1. **KUGW** : Keep Up the Good Work
2. **KUFC** : Keep Your Fingers Crossed
3. **KUPO** : Keep Your Pants On 
4. **KUNC** : Keep Your Nose Clean
5. **KUBC** : Keep Your Bum Clean

_data.title: Quantum Computers
_data.description: A simple understanding of Quantum Computers
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What are Quantum Computers
cards.a: Computers that harness the power of **quantum computing** to solve complex problems that today's most powerful supercomputers cannot solve, and never will

cards.q: So, what is Quantum Computing
cards.a: It is a different form of *computing* that uses the power of something called **quantum states** of a particle

cards.q: And, what are Quantum States of a particle
Are Quantum computers better than classical computers
cards.a: Yes. They have the potential to be faster and more powerful than classical computers.

cards.q: How much faster can they potentially process
cards.a: It is said that such computers could process about 1 trillion chess moves per second!

cards.q: Cannot classical computers reach that computing power
What are the problems that  only Quantum computing can solve
cards.a:
These are complex mathematical problems. For example:
1. What are the Prime factors of a number
2. Asking questions like: is some mathematical phenomenon true **for all** values 
3. Solving the **Tail Assignment Problem** : assigning airplanes to flights with the goal of minimizing connection times between flights subject to maintenance constraints

cards.q: Cannot some of the problems be solved using Statistical algorithms in classical computers
What are **cubits** in quantum processing
cards.a: Quantum bits, which are used for quantum computing which can hold multiple values

cards.q: What is a Quantum Turing Machine
cards.a:
1. It is an is an abstract machine to model the effects of a quantum computer
2. Turing Machines are simple abstract computational devices intended to help investigate the extent and limitations of what can be computed 
3. Also called: **Universal Quantum Computer**

cards.q: When was quantum computing first initiated
cards.a: In the 1980s

cards.q: Which are the companies that have built Quantum computers
cards.a:
A partial list includes:
1. IBM
2. Google
3. Microsoft
4. Toshiba
5. D-wave Systems

cards.q: Which was the first Quantum computer company
cards.a: D-wave Systems

_data.title: Space Tourism
_data.description: A summary of state of Space Tourism
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What does Space Tourism mean
cards.a: Travelling to Space for recreational purposes

cards.q: How different is that from Space Exploration
cards.a: Space Exploration is conducted by Astromers, Astronauts and other Scientific personnel to study and discover outer space

cards.q: When did Space Tourism begin
cards.a: At the end of the 1990s when a Russian company MirCorp, who maintained the space station *Mir* signed a deal with US company Space Adventures to sell a trip to the space station

cards.q: Who was the first Space tourist
cards.a: Mr Dennis Tito, a US millionnaire, who paid $20 million for the trip in Apr-2001

cards.q: How long was this trip
cards.a: Tito spent a week at the International Space Station (ISS), Mir

cards.q: Who were some of the other toursists who undertook recreational space travel
cards.a:
- Mark Shuttleworth of South Africa in 2002
- Gregory Olsen of US in 2005
- Anousheh Ansari of US in 2006 (*first female space tourist*)

cards.q: What is an International Space Station
cards.a: A modular space station at low orbit

cards.q: At what height is an ISS
cards.a: Approximately 400 kms (250 mi)

cards.q: How many ISS are there today
cards.a:
As of now only 2 are operational
1. International Space Station
2. Tiangong Space Station

cards.q: Why is Space Tourism gaining interest now
cards.a: Because NASA of US has announced that they will permit private astronauts to the ISS

cards.q: What is Orbital Space Flights
cards.a: Space flights where the spacecraft remains at the orbit of the earth at around 80 kms (51 mi) and to remain in space for at least one orbit

cards.q: What is the boundary of the Earth's atmosphere
cards.a: It is called the **Kármán line** and is defined as 100 kms (54 nautical mi; 62 mi; 330,000 ft) above Earth's mean sea level

cards.q: What is one of the challenges of Space Tourism
cards.a: To keep the costs of such travel lower, spacecrafts have to be reusable

cards.q: What gave impetus to space tourism
cards.a: In 2004, there was a $10 million prize (**X Prize**) offered to a non-governmental organisation that could launch a reusable crewed spacecraft twice within two weeks

cards.q: Who won that prize
cards.a: **SpaceShipOne**, funded by Virgin Galactic and designed by American engineer **Burt Rutan** of Scaled Composites, won the X Prize

cards.q: Which companies are offering Space Tourism
cards.a:
1. Virgin Galactic founded by Richard Branson
2. Blue Origin founded by Jeff Bezos

cards.q: What are Suborbital Spaceflights
cards.a: A spaceflight in which the spacecraft reaches outer space, but does not complete one orbital revolution

cards.q: What was the durations of the suborbital flights offered by Blue Origin
cards.a: approx 10 minutes

cards.q: In recent times who were some celebrities that visited space
cards.a:
1. Richard Branson, founder of Virgin
2. Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon
3. William Shatner of *Star Trek* fame
4. Yusaku Maezawa, a Japanese Billionaire

cards.q: What is 3D printing in a sentence
cards.a: Creation of 3 dimensional products using a special type of printer

cards.q: How is it different from normal printing
cards.a: Printing, as we commonly understand, is applying ink or paint in two dimensions on surfaces like paper, cloth, plastic, wood. While 3D print is a type of manufacturing that creates products like toys.

cards.q: Is it the same as **Additive** printing
cards.a: Yes. Because layers of a material are added to make the product.

cards.q: What type of products are popularly made using 3D printers
cards.a:
- toys
- equipment frames like bicycle handles
- sporting goods
- car components
- music instruments

cards.q: What are the advantages of 3D printing
cards.a:
Unlike conventional manufacturing, 3D printing can be done:
- in a small place / workshop (even at home)
- with minimal investments
- in small quantities 
- for prototyping product ideas before full-scale production

cards.q: How is a 3-dimensional product *printed* using a printer
cards.a:
1. The 3D printing process turns a whole object into thousands of tiny little slices or layers
2. Then, each slice is made from the bottom using special material
3. Thes tiny layers stick together to form a solid object

cards.q: Is a 3D printer a special type of printer
cards.a: Yes. Unlike the normal printers that use ink to apply on the surface of materials like paper, a 3D printer uses certain materials in power form to form the layers of the product.

cards.q: What are some of the materials used
cards.a:
The materials used need to be in powder form with glue.
1. **Plastic** is the most popular used material
2. **Metal powders** like Aluminium, Steel etc where strength is required
3. **Carbon Fibre** used popularly as a coating over plastic
4. **Graphene** because of its strength and conductivity

cards.q: How are **instructions** given to make a 3D product
cards.a:
1. 3D printers require a computer to which it is attached
2. It uses a specialised software called **Computer Aided Design** (CAD)   
3. The product is designed with the order in which the layers have to be applied
4. Finally, the printer is loaded with the desired material (*similar to how we load an ink cartridge*)

cards.q: Is there a limit to what can printed using 3D printers
cards.a:
Yes.
1. Only certain type of materials are available that can be used
2. Since it uses an additive technology, only products that will not easily fail (*break, bend or fracture*) by this layer method can be manufactured
3. There is a limit to the dimensions of what can be printed

cards.q: Is it cheaper to make a product using 3D printing
cards.a: Depends. It is definitely cheaper when *not-so-large quantities* are to be made and when the product has some *intricate design* where the die costs may be prohibitive.

cards.q: What are some of the newer items being experimented with 3D printing
cards.a:
1. **Houses**: Pre-fabricated houses have been in vogue for a while. Now, these prefab components can be made using 3D printers.
2. **Car components**: Auto ancilliaries are being made esp with new materials being used in 3D printing
3. **Jewellery**: Intricate designs can now be made via a computer

cards.q: What is the full form of AR
cards.a: Augmented Reality

cards.q: What happens in AR
cards.a: Simply put, when you point the camera of your mobile to an object, *say a flower*, details of the flower may appear as an overlay on the screen. This is via AR technology.

cards.q: So it enhances real-world experiences in a way
cards.a:
Yes. In short, it allows you to interact with that object the camera focuses on. These include:
1. Giving information on the screen
2. Playing a video or audio related to that object
3. Or simply offering a menu from which to choose one or many options

cards.q: How does it work
cards.a:
1. The system captures the image to where the camera is pointed
2. Shares it with a software running either on the device or an internet server
3. An AI algorithm recognises (a best estimate) the object.
4. That results in information being put out about that object

cards.q: What are the uses of AR
cards.a:
1. Classroom Education
2. Medical Training
3. Repair and Maintenance of equipment
4. Retailing when browsing articles
5. Tourism

cards.q: Is this not similar to QR codes
cards.a: Yes, in the sense that an image is used to identify the product. Except that in a QR code system, someone will have to create a code for every object and place it near the object to be scanned. In the case of AR, you simple scan the object.

cards.q: What are AR glasses
cards.a: These are spectacles that serve the same function that the camera of a mobile does. Wearing it, the user can focus on an object, and visible on the lens will be information about it.

cards.q: Where does the AR system get this information form
How is AR different from VR (Virtual Reality)
Can AR and VR co-exist
cards.a: Yes. In a VR-based virtual world, one can *point* at objects which will bring in additional information about that object.

cards.q: Has AR become popular
How does such an app work
cards.a:
1. Imagine that you have picked an item, *say a sofa*, from the digital store front.
2. Then, point the AR app to a part of the room where you would like to place it.
3. The app has the ability to measure distances and the space available.
4. Then, as you place the sofa at the desired place, it can estimate whether it fits or not.
5. Further, as a consumer, you can check the suitability of the item in the room and try out various uphosteries.

cards.q: What is Bitcoin
cards.a: It is a type of cryptocurrency

cards.q: What is a Cryptocurrency
Is Bitcoin the only cryptocurrency
cards.a: No. There are a few thousands of cryptocurrencies. Bitcoin is one of them and the first to be introduced.

cards.q: What do you mean by digital or virtual currency
cards.a: Unlike the paper or coin representation of value of money, think of a digital currency as a unique string of characters which holds some value

cards.q: Besides being digital in what way is it different from any normal currency
cards.a: Traditional currencies are endorsed (and controlled) by the Central Bank of a country. Bitcoin has no such governing body.

cards.q: Does this mean no one owns Bitcoin
cards.a: Yes. Of sorts. There is no central bank, or banks who endorse a currency exchange between two parties like we have in conventional currency operations.

cards.q: Who created Bitcoin
cards.a: A person by the name of **Satoshi Nakamoto**. No one knows who he is (or they are).  It is the name of a presumed pseudonymous person (or persons) who developed bitcoin, authored the bitcoin white paper, and created and deployed bitcoin's original reference implementation.

cards.q: Can I send Bitcoin to another person
cards.a: Yes, you can send bitcoins to others just as well receive bitcoins from others

cards.q: Similar to how I would send or receive in a digital wallet
What can I buy with Bitcoin
cards.a: Depends. Some e-commerce sites accept bitcoin as a mode of payment in which case goods or services can be purchased using it.

cards.q: Does the price of Bitcoin change over time
cards.a: Yes. It does based on market forces. Much like shares. Except that it is unregulated.

cards.q: Are there denominations in Bitcoin, like we have in normal currencies.
So how much is 1 satoshi
Is there a transaction fee charged
cards.a: When any bitcoin transaction is done (send or receive) there is a transaction fee that is charged and net of that the amount is put in the wallet of the receiver

cards.q: Where are all the transactions stored
cards.a: Bitcoin works on a Blockchain ledger system (*separate deck available*). The transactions are stored in the ledger across all servers of the Bitcoin network.

cards.q: Does this mean every transaction is on the ledger and know to one and all
cards.a: Yes. Except there is no way of linking a person to a particular bitcoin.

cards.q: How secure is it from someone else stealing money from your bitcoin wallet
cards.a: Almost impossible. Think of it like a password. If someone has your password, then they can transfer the bitcoin to others.

cards.q: How can I buy a Bitcoin
cards.a: In an exchange similar to how you buy shares. Someone sells you a bitcoin (or part of) based on current market prices

cards.q: Who maintain the servers of the Bitcoin network
cards.a: Folks who would like to **mine** bitcoins!

cards.q: What is **Mining** in bitcoin terminology
cards.a: The servers that constitute the bitcoin distributed network **work hard** to maintain the system. For that they are rewarded by bitcoins (or part of). The process is called *Mining* and they are called **miners**.

cards.q: Can Bitcoin be infinitely generated or is it regulated in some form
cards.a: As per the original paper, it was decided to limit the total number of bitcoins to **21 million**

cards.q: Why is there a limit set for number of bitcoins
cards.a: This is to emulate the concept similar to that of physical gold viz there is a finite quantity to be mined

cards.q: And so far how many have been mined so far
cards.a: Around **19 million** bitcoins

cards.q: How much more time will it take for the remainder 2 million to be mined
cards.a: By some estimates that will take place around 2040

cards.q: Then, what happens after that
cards.a: No more bitcoins will be mined, of course. However, miners (*folks running the servers*) will continue to earn with transaction fee.

cards.q: Can cryptocoins be pegged to an existing currency
cards.a: Yes, it can. There are numerous cryptocoins that are pegged say to the US dollar. But Bitcoin is not one of them.

cards.q: Is the **Ledger** in Blockchain Ledger a ledger that is commonly understood
So what is a **Blocked Ledger**
cards.a: A Block Ledger is a group of transactions called a **Block**

cards.q: What, then, is a **Blockchain Ledger**
cards.a:
A Blockchain Ledger is one when the *blocks* of a ledger are **chained together**.
 
For example: 
- if T1 (transaction 1) to T5 are in, say, block B1
- and, T6 to T12 in block B2
- We chain block B2 to the end of B1

Then these become a Blockchain Ledger

cards.q: Isn't this how all most digital ledgers work
What does **Decentralised** Ledger mean
cards.a: If a ledger is not controlled by a central computer it is called a Decentralised Ledger

cards.q: What does **Distributed** Ledger mean
cards.a: If a ledger, like a Blockchain Ledger, is available on multiple servers it is a Distributed Ledger

cards.q: What is a **node** in Blockchain terminology
cards.a: Another name for servers (computers) in the Blockchain network

cards.q: Are multiple copies of the data stored on multiple servers of the Blockchain network
cards.a: Yes.

cards.q: Is it not a waste of resources
cards.a: No, since this is the only way to prevent a single ownership of data

cards.q: What is wrong with someone storing all the data
cards.a:
This gives that party leverage to control the use of that data. 
 
Examples of centralised data are:
1. Government institutions like the Central Bank or Finance Ministry etc
2. Social networks like: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram etc
3. Digital Marketplaces like Amazon etc

cards.q: So who owns the data in a Blockchain ledger system
cards.a: Collectively, all the nodes of the Blockchain distributed system manage the data

cards.q: Then, would not the node control the data similar to how a central server has control of the data
Consensus? Meaning what
cards.a: If any node makes a change to the ledger viz. adds, removes or updates an entry then other nodes will need to validate that change before the ledger gets updated

cards.q: And how is that done
cards.a: All via the underlying blockchain ledger software

cards.q: So who can add / change the Ledger
cards.a: Only the owner of the transaction. And this is managed via encryption methods to prevent fraud.

cards.q: Why is blockchain getting the sort of attention it does
cards.a: Because it removes the existence of a third-party to validate a transaction between two individuals

cards.q: What are examples of third-party intermediaries that exist in the world today
cards.a:
1. Government who confirms that currency given by one individual to another is authentic
2. The Land records department who confirms that land owned by someone is truly that claimed by the owner
3. Digital Marketplaces that confirm the sale of an item from a seller to a buyer

cards.q: How can intermediaries be avoided via a Blockchain system
cards.a:
Yes.
1. Bitcoin is an example of a currency that is not controlled by any State or Government
2. The NFT is a classic example of the sale and purchase of assets without any broker

_data.title: What is CBDC
_data.description: Info about the Central Bank Digital Currency
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is full form of CBDC
cards.a: Central Bank Digital Currency

cards.q: What is a CBDC
cards.a: It is a legal currency in digital format issued by the Central Bank of a country

cards.q: How is a digital currency different from normal currency
cards.a: Currencies traditionally have been in paper (polymer) and metal form. The digital currency is a third form which is digital.

cards.q: Will the value of the digital currency be different from that of the normal currency
cards.a: No. It will be the same.

cards.q: How is digital currency payment different from online payment
cards.a:
Online Payment
1. is a digital method via which a user (account) authorises payment to another user (account)
2. needs to go through a bank settlement system
3. is a convenience over traditional banking methods for money transfers

Digital Currency Payment
1. is immediately settled, like paying in cash
2. No bank settlement system

cards.q: What are the benefits of Digital Currency
cards.a:
1. Instantaneous transfer
2. No intermediary process like bank settlement

cards.q: Is it possible to transfer paper money to digital currency and vice-versa
cards.a: Yes, it should be possible. Think of it similar to transferring an amount from your account from one bank to another of your own account in another bank.

cards.q: How will the popularity of digital currency help any government
cards.a: With increased digital financial transactions, the burden of managing physical money reduces

cards.q: Would global payments be possible between digital currencies
cards.a: Yes. And it is being discussed as a possibility. This will make the transfer of money between two parties instantaneously.

cards.q: Is the CBDC similar to Bitcoin
cards.a:
No.
1. Bitcoin is a crypto currency that does not have the backing of any government or central bank of a country.
2. Bitcoin is not legal in most countries.
3. Bitcoin rates fluctuate on buy/sell economics with no intervention unlike national currencies
4. Bitcoins are not easily tradable for goods and services like digital currencies would be

cards.q: Is there any similarity of a digital currency with Bitcoin
cards.a: In that the underlying technology viz blockchain ledger *may be used* in both cases

cards.q: Has any country issued CBDCs
cards.a: No. But many have begun pilots.

cards.q: Which are the countries that are evaluating CBDCs
cards.a:
1. UK
2. China
3. Russia
4. Japan
5. US
6. India

cards.q: What is Hyperloop
cards.a: A new high speed mode of transport on ground for passenger and freight

cards.q: How is it different from road and rail transport
cards.a: Passenger *pods* or cargo *pods* travel through *tubes* at very high speed

cards.q: What is a Pod
cards.a: Think of it as a compartment specially designed for hyperloop technology

cards.q: What are the speeds at which these pods move
cards.a: Reaching speeds above 600 kmph! ... the technology promises to reach over 1000 kmph

cards.q: How do Hyperloops work
cards.a:
1. Tubes are laid out between pod terminals
2. The air within the tube is sucked out to provide a frictionless movement of the pods
3. The pods accelerate using electric propulsion
4. The pods floats in the tube using magnetic levitation and guides

cards.q: How many passengers can travel in a pod
cards.a: Depends on the pod. Current tests have shown seating capacity of 20 to 40 passengers

cards.q: Do passengers feel uncomfortable during travel
cards.a: Not as per test reports. Passengers feel *stronger than* when one takes off in a plane but not discomforting as reported.

cards.q: What are the advantages of Hyperloop technology
cards.a:
1. Transportation will be faster
2. It is supposed to be built quicker and cheaper than rail infrastructure

cards.q: Is Hyperloop tunnel always built below the ground
cards.a: No. The technology is independent of below or over land. However, at times it may be easier to bore a tunnel below land to overcome challenges of creating a path.

cards.q: What is the diameter of the tunnel
cards.a: In some of the proof of concept runs, the tunnels have been between 3 and 4 metres

cards.q: Which are the companies developing Hyperloop travel infrastructure
cards.a:
1. The Boring Company
2. Virgin Hyperloop
3. Hyperloop Transportation
4. Transpod

cards.q: Has any company started Hyperloop operations
cards.a: No. It has not yet been commercially launched.

cards.q: Has any test being conducted with passengers
cards.a:
Yes. Virgin Hyperloop were the first to conduct a test with human passengers.
- on 8-Nov-2020
- on a 500m track in Nevada, US
- took 15 seconds
- reached speed of 172 km/h or 107 mph
- passengers
  - Lara Luchian and Josh Giegel 
  - Tanay Manjrekar and Anne Huynh

cards.q: Which are some of the Hyperloop projects underway
cards.a:
1. 2km *proof of concept* in **Hawthorne** in Los Angeles county, US
2. 48 kms between cities **Mumbai and Pune** of India
3. 690 km between **Dallas and Laredo** in Texas, US
4. 951 km between **Jeddah and Riyadh** in Saudi Arabia

cards.q: Who conceived of the Hyperloop
cards.a: There has been some mention of a similar technology by an inventor named **George Medhurst** in 1799

cards.q: Why is Elon Musk being credited with the Hyperloop
cards.a: Because, Elon Musk reignited interest with his *Hyperloop Alpha* paper in August 2013, which set out how a modern system would work and how much it would cost

cards.q: How to describe Metaverse in a single sentence
cards.a: It is a 3D virtual world accessible via internet

cards.q: What can be done in Metaverse
cards.a:
1. Play games on a virtual playground or arena
2. Learn in a virtual classroom
3. Train to operate virtual machines
4. Just hang around in an area and socialise with people
5. Buy property!

cards.q: Who coined the word
cards.a: It was first described in the 1992 novel **Snow Crash** by Neal Stephenson

cards.q: When did it all start
cards.a: Technology is usually built bit by bit and Metaverse is no different. Virtual online communities were built in the early 2000s. *Second Life* in 2003 being one of the most popular.

cards.q: Why is Metaverse getting popular now
cards.a:
Time is ripe due to progress in:
- 5G networks
- more computing power and memory in small devices
- coming of age of and VR and AR
- need to work remotely

cards.q: Do we need special equipment to participate in Metaverse
cards.a:
1. A desktop or notebook computer
2. A Virtual Reality (VR) headset for an immersive experience
3. Tactile Gloves will help feel objects in this  world
4. Wrist sensors to feel sensation (e.g. *Bow & Arrow games*) 
5. Augmented Reality (AR) Glasses to interact with objects

cards.q: Do I need to walk at home to move in the virtual world
cards.a:
No! That would be disastrous. There are a number of ways this is accomplished
1. Using the keyboard one can move in two directions
2. People wear a harness around them and walk like in a treadmill
3. In some cases, you may just point to a place and you get *teleported* there

cards.q: How would we use the keyboard to move
cards.a:
For example:
1. Moving the up and down arrow takes you forward or backward
2. Similarly the left and right arrow moves you left or right
3. Perhaps, a shift + left will turn your view to the left

While keyboard equivalents are available, having a VR headset makes the experience immersive.

cards.q: How do we focus or point to an object
cards.a:
Just like we have a cursor on a normal computer, so is the case in a Metaverse world. 
1. The cursor can be pointed to an object and clicked to select via a mouse.
2. Or if one uses a headset, then we turn in the desired direction and position the cursor on that object and tap on a button on the side of the headset.

cards.q: Can we move objects in Metaverse
cards.a: Yes, this is much like in the physical world, where using the hand gloves, you could touch objects, move them, lift them and place them elsewhere

cards.q: What are **Hand Gloves**
cards.a: These are electronic gloves with controllers that are connected to the headset so that movement of one's hands get translated to gestures in the virtual world

cards.q: Is it similar to the purpose of joy sticks in gaming
cards.a: Yes. These versatile hand controllers can be used in 3D environments.

cards.q: Can we speak to others in Metaverse
Then, how is it different from video conferencing
cards.a: It is 3D and the experience gives you a feeling of being in the other place

cards.q: Can we see the other person like we do in a video
cards.a: No. Everyone is represented by an **avatar**. Though many create avatars which have a resemblance to their own self.

cards.q: How are avatars created similar to oneself
cards.a: Avatar creation softwares are available that take a bunch of snaps from different positions or using a camera to create an avatar. These avatars have a fair resemblance to the person. Once made, it can be kept as an indentity for all worlds.

cards.q: Would not people make avatars that are different from how they look
cards.a: Yes. And very often that is the case. In fact, one of the likely reasons for its popularity is that a person can be a very **different** one in this virtual world.

cards.q: Why are people buying space in Metaverse worlds
cards.a:
All real estate investments are for two purposes:
1. To stay or enjoy the property
2. As investment to sell it when it appreciates      

In the case of Metaverse, it is often the latter.

cards.q: Is VR experiences similar to the **Real Player One** movie
cards.a: Yes. The movie which was based on the book by *Ernest Cline* explored how people escape the problems of earth by going into a virtual world ... except a movie is a movie!

cards.q: What is the full form of NFT
cards.a:
**Non-fungible Token**

- Non-fungible: meaning that it is *unique* and *cannot be changed*
- Token is a *representation* of something and in this case it is a digital token

In short, NFT is a digital representation of something that is unique and cannot change.

cards.q: What are some of the examples of things that can be NFTs
cards.a:
1. Artworks
2. Music, Videos
3. Memorabilia, Collectibles
4. Tweets
5. Alcohol (Yes!)
6. Source code (programs)
7. Virtual real estate

Almost anything.

cards.q: Does the NFT contain the digital item or asset?
cards.a: No. Again the NFT is a representation of the item, whether it is physical or digital

cards.q: How can NFTs be offered for physical items?
cards.a: Remember an NFT is a **representation** for something, which can be a physical item too

cards.q: What do we mean by representation of an item
cards.a: Think of how a *library card* in a physical Library is a representation of the physical book that is stored on the shelf

cards.q: Does that mean that the asset, digital or physical, is stored elsewhere
Does the owner of an NFT get copyright to the underlying asset
Does this mean that an artwork (digital or otherwise) can be owned by several people
It looks like there can be different terms in which an NFT can be sold. Right?
cards.a: Yes, the terms of the NFT are specified and part of the NFT

cards.q: Why would someone buy an NFT
cards.a: Because it is of some value to them and in most cases it's value, they believe, would appreciate over time. Just like *any other asset*.

cards.q: Why would a creator sell an NFT
cards.a: It is another medium to sell something someone has created

cards.q: Why would someone sell an item as a NFT instead of using shops or auction houses or brokers
Do physical goods bought get sent to the buyer
Does owning a NFT give the buyer exclusive access to the asset
Would this not diminish the value of the asset
Which was the first NFT that was sold by a major auction house
cards.a:
A digital artwork called **Everydays: The First 5000 Days** by Beeple.

1. This is a collage of 5000 digital images created by Mike Winkelmann (Beeple) 
2. This was sold for USD 69 million.

cards.q: What are some of the popular NFTs that have been sold
cards.a:
1. Beeple's "Everydays: The First 5000 Days"
2. Jack Dorsey first tweet
3. Distillers William Grant and Son sold 15 bottles of 46-year-old Glenfiddich whisky for $18,000 a piece
4. NBA shots sports collectibles
5. This Changed Everything is an NFT of the source code used for one of the earliest versions of the World Wide Web sold for USD 5.4 million

cards.q: What is **The Merge**
cards.a:
1. The Merge is a digital artwork created by an anonymous digital artist nicknamed *Pak*
2. It was sold on Dec. 6, 2021 for $91.8 million
3. The piece was fractionalized to 312,686 pieces distributed to 28,983 buyers
4. The Merge was a single artwork composed of a collection of **masses** that users could buy
5. These pieces could be *stockpiled* to make a bigger mass and sell it on the secondary market

cards.q: What is a Meme
cards.a: It is  is an idea, behavior, image, or style that is spread through social media platforms

cards.q: How is it pronounced
cards.a: /miːm/ MEEM

cards.q: In what digital forms are Meems
cards.a: Usually Photos or Videos, though it can be a block of text

cards.q: What is an example of a Meme
Who coined the word: Meme
cards.a: It is credited to evolutionary biologist **Richard Dawkins** who referred to it in his book, *The Selfish Gene* (1976) who described it as *an idea, behavior, or style that rapidly spreads from person to person in a culture*

cards.q: Why do people Meem
cards.a:
- to be funny or humourous
- to be sarcastic
- to teach a life lesson
- to be shocking

cards.q: Do companies too *meme* or just individuals
cards.a:
Companies do meme and it could be for one of many reasons:
- to share info in a fun format
- to humanise the brand
- for higher engagement with the audience
- to demonstrate some complicated concept

_data.title: QUAD
_data.description: A overview of the QUAD dialog
_data.author: rmr

cards.q: What is QUAD an abbreviation of
cards.a: The Quadrilateral Security Dialogue

cards.q: QUAD is a dialogue between which countries
cards.a:
It is a strategic security dialogue between:
- Australia 
- India
- Japan
- USA

cards.q: What was the objective of QUAD
cards.a: to work for a free, open, prosperous and inclusive Indo-Pacific region

cards.q: When was QUAD initiated
cards.a: In **2007** by the then Japanese Prime Minister *Shinzo Abe*

cards.q: If it was initiated so many years back, why the sudden interest in 2020s
cards.a:
- In 2008 Australia terminated the quadrilateral causing a lull
- In 2017 Japan invited the member countries reinvigorating the quadrilateral
- Changes in geo-politics esp with China's *Belt and Roat initiative* added the right fuel

cards.q: Why is it viewed as an anti-Chinese
Is Quad a military alliance
cards.a: No. In the words of the foreign ministers of the Quad countries, it is *to reaffirm shared commitment to rules-based order in the Indo-Pacific region*.

cards.q: When was the first Quad Summit held
cards.a: In March 2021, US President Joe Biden hosted a *virtual summit*

cards.q: Is Quad like an Asian NATO
What are some of the other areas that are jointly being worked upon
cards.a:
- Anti-covid vaccine distribution
- Supply Chain availability  
- Climate Control
- Education

cards.q: What is Robotic Surgery
cards.a: They are types of surgeries that are done using robotic systems

cards.q: Are Robotic Surgeries done by machines
cards.a: No. They assist surgeons in performing complicated and delicate surgeries

cards.q: What are common Robotic Surgeries
cards.a:
1. Gynecologic Surgery
2. Prostate Surgery
3. Head and Neck Surgery
4. Gastrointestinal Surgery
5. Heart Surgery

cards.q: What are the benefits of such surgeries
cards.a:
- Surgeons get better view of what is happening
- Reduced pain and discomfort
- Faster recovery time 
- Smaller incisions hence reduced risk of infection
- Reduced blood loss and transfusions

cards.q: Are these surgeries safe
cards.a: Robotic surgery involves risk - *similar to those of conventional open surgery* -  such as a small risk of infection and other complications

cards.q: In what way do these robots help doctors perform surgery
cards.a: Doctors can now perform many types of complex procedures with more **precision**, **flexibility** and **control** than is possible with conventional techniques

cards.q: What are the parts of a surgical robot
cards.a:
1. Surgeon's console
2. Patient cart
3. Vision cart

cards.q: What is in the **Surgeon's console**
cards.a:
The console is the place where the surgeon:
- sits and sees what is happening
- has master control of how the instruments need to move
- can view high-definition real-time 3D images

cards.q: What is in the **Patient cart**
cards.a:
The Patient cart:
- is kept next to the patient’s bed
- holds the camera and the instruments that are required for the surgery

cards.q: What is in the **Vision cart**
cards.a: The Vision cart is in charge of enabling the communication to take place seamlessly between all the components

cards.q: Which is the most popular Surgical Robotic System
cards.a: The Da Vinci System

cards.q: When was Robotic Surgeries first done
cards.a: in the 1980s

cards.q: Can any surgeon perform robotic surgery
cards.a: With proper training

cards.q: Can robotic surgery be performed remotely
cards.a: Yes. It is also referred to as **Telesurgery**

cards.q: When was the first telesurgery done
cards.a:
The first telesurgery was:
- performed by Professor Jacques Marescaux on 7-Sep-2001 
- performed in Strasbourg, France
- called the **Lindbergh Operation** 
- a telesurgery-assisted *cholecystectomy*
- completed in 54 minutes

cards.q: Web 3.0 😳? Did we have a 1.0 and 2.0
cards.a:
Yes. 
**Web 1.0** is termed for the first phase of internet when the protocols were defined and companies started putting up their web sites.
 
**Web 2.0** is termed when folks started using the internet for social media apps like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram etc.

cards.q: So what is new in Web 3.0
cards.a:
It is an idea where the web content is based on:
- **blockchain technology** (*separate deck available*) 
- with **decentralisation servers** 
- and **token-based economics**

It is characterised by users owning the content they create viz. blogs, posts, opinions etc.

cards.q: So how is decentralised servers different from today's web servers
cards.a: Currently all the information is available on a single server (*or server farm*). All owned and controlled by the organisation who set up them up. In Web 3.0, the content will be **distributed on multiple servers** (as per the blockchain technology).

cards.q: And what is the token-based economics mean
cards.a: That the creators of such a system could *offer their content* using crypto coins which users may have to furnish to *gain access* to information.

cards.q: What is wrong with Web 2.0 that needed a change
cards.a:
Some of the ills of the current internet usage are:
1. Thanks to the popularity of social media, big-tech internet companies like Facebook, Google, Twitter have become powerful and have the ability to influence and control people.
2. The privacy of most people using these networks is being compromised.
3. These internet companies are leveraging the content created by news companies and individuals; thereby robbing them of their rightful revenue.

cards.q: Who, then, would run the servers of any Web 3.0 website and why
cards.a: It is in the same manner in which the bitcoin and other blockchain networks work today. A set of *people/organisations* unconnected with one another. Except that they need *financial incentives* to be part of it. And that is provided by the token economics that we spoke about earlier,

cards.q: Are there web 3.0 websites in existence today
cards.a: Tech folks are experimenting with it but none of the popular websites have moved to this proposed idea

cards.q: Are there critics to Web 3.0
cards.a:
There are many who believe that:
- it is not going to be easy to implement a blockchain web
- it still is going to be controlled by the few companies who are controlling the crypto world
- that people in general are not ready for token economics for accessing content

cards.q: What is the economics of current internet
cards.a:
1. Corporations and / or Government set up the infrastructure required to run the internet servers
2. They provide the service usually free or at minimal charges
3. In return they capitalise the usage of their service by advertisements and/or influencing the users

cards.q: How would the decentralised system protect privacy and ownership of content
cards.a:
1. Blockchain distributed systems rely on encryption to prevent stealing of information
2. This encryption also ensures no manipulation of someone else's data
3. The distributed system ensures no unauthorised change to content
4. With no single owner to the networks governments cannot access / request access to this information

cards.q: Is Metaverse part of Web 3.0
cards.a: Folks are suggesting that the access to the Web 3.0 content should be via a Metaverse (*separate deck available*) interface

cards.q: What is the full form of VR
cards.a: Virtual Reality

cards.q: What does VR do
cards.a: VR is the use of computer technology to **simulate a 3D environment**

cards.q: What are some of the examples of VR
cards.a:
1. Virtual tours of places of interest
2. Train soldiers with the use of simulations
3. Educational training from remote locations
4. Architectural walkthru's of places
5. Virtual Shopping

cards.q: What is required to experience VR
cards.a:
1. A VR Headset that provides the immersive experience
2. The headset or mobile placed in it should be connected to the internet
3. Access to the virtual environment that is prepared by someone

cards.q: What is a VR Headset
cards.a: It is a head-worn apparatus that covers one eyes for an **immersive experience**. It is also called *VR Googles*.

cards.q: How does it look
Does a VR headset require a mobile
Which sensors are required for a VR experience
cards.a:
Either from within the headset or via the smartphone, VRs use some combination of:
- accelerometer 
- gyroscope 
- magnetometer
- proximity sensor 

all to detect the user's motion in the virtual world.

cards.q: What is an Accelerometer
cards.a: It is a tool that measures acceleration of the body as the user moves across the virtual world

cards.q: What is a Gyroscope
cards.a: It is a tool to sense angular rotational velocity and acceleration of the body as the user turns

cards.q: What is a Magnetometer
cards.a: It is a tool to detect the relative orientation of your mobile / VR relative to the Earth's magnetic north

cards.q: Do we see other folks in the virtual world
cards.a: Yes. But as **avatars**.

cards.q: What are avatars
cards.a: In VR terms, an avatar is a **3D graphical representation** of a user or the user's character or *persona*

cards.q: Can we turn using VR
cards.a: Yes. It provides a 360 degree view of the virtual world. So turning and moving your head will change the view in all directions.

cards.q: Can we move in the virtual world using VR headset
cards.a: Yes. When viewing through the headset there is a cursor (*much like the cursor of our computer*). Often, placing the cursor ahead and **tapping a button** on the side of the headset *transports* you there.

cards.q: Can we speak to others in the virtual world
cards.a: It depends on how the virtual environment has been prepared; if they enable talking to others in the virtual room, then the **mic** and **speaker** (of the VR or mobile) will be used for communication

cards.q: Who prepares a virtual world
cards.a:
1. The Virtual world is prepared via a software running on some servers
2. The Virtual elements like roads, building, walls, seats etc are needed to be created using computer graphics
3. When we connect to that world (*like visiting a website*) one can move around and explore the world

cards.q: Which companies make VR headsets
cards.a:
Some of the popular names are:
1. Oculus Rift
2. Sony Playstation VR
3. HTC Vive
4. Samsung Gear

cards.q: What is Wordle
cards.a: It is a web-based word game where a player has to guess a hidden word

cards.q: What are the rules of Wordle
cards.a:
- The player has six attempts to guess a hidden word
- After each guess, feedback is given to the player in the form of coloured tiles indicating if alphabets matched and/or occupy the correct position
- The player wins if the hidden word is correctly guessed within six attempts, else loses

cards.q: What feedback do the coloured tiles indicate
cards.a:
- An alphabet in a green tile indicates that the alphabet is present in the hidden word and in the correct position
- An alphabet in a yellow tile indicates that the alphabet is present in the hidden word but is in the wrong position
- An alphabet in a grey tile indicates that the alphabet is not present in the hidden word

cards.q: What kind of words are hidden
cards.a: A five-letter valid word in the English language

cards.q: What words can be guessed
cards.a: A player’s guess must be a valid five-letter word in the English language

cards.q: What is the time limit to guess a word
cards.a: There is no time limit to guess a word

cards.q: What is cost of playing
cards.a: Wordle can be played for free

cards.q: How many times can Wordle be played
cards.a: Wordle has one hidden word per day, so it can be played at most once a day

cards.q: Who developed Wordle
cards.a: Josh Wardle developed Wordle, initially for himself and his partner to play, before sharing it publicly

cards.q: When was Wordle released publicly
cards.a: October, 2021

cards.q: Who owns Wordle
cards.a: The New York Times Company purchased Wordle from Josh Wardle on 31st January, 2022
